1.title: Chelmsford woman completes 100th ultra-marathon
1.summary: "After the birth of my last child I put on a significant amount of weight so something had to be done because my health was going to go down," she said.

2.title: DeSantis push for more control of Disney special district gets approval from Florida legislature
2.summary:
Under the bill, the district's existing board will be replaced by a five-member board hand-picked by DeSantis.
He called on lawmakers to strip the company of its special governing powers, which they did in a special session last year, voting to dissolve the Reedy Creek Improvement District at the end of May 2023.
It also renames Reedy Creek as the Central Florida Tourism Oversight District.
The final page of the 189-page bill states: "The Reedy Creek Improvement District is not dissolved as of June 1, 2023, but continues in full force and effect under its new name."
Fitch Ratings, which put Reedy Creek Improvement District's debt on watch for a negative bond rating, told CNN in a statement that the proposed legislation "appears to address key uncertainties."

3.title: West Virginia mixed martial arts coach offers security for local drag show
3.summary:
A group of West Virginia mixed martial arts (MMA) fighters are offering security to help a local drag show that canceled an event after receiving threats.
MMA coach Johnny Haught and his trainees volunteered to provide security to the Primanti Bros restaurant in Wheeling, West Virginia, for the show it was set to host.
Organizers announced that they would be cancelling the drag brunch scheduled for 26 February, after performers and patrons received threats, reported Outsports.
“We couldn’t wait to party with you all, support the local LGBTQIA+ community, and show that a little glitter never hurt anyone,” wrote the event’s organizers, S&S Productions, a Pennsylvania-based LGBTQ+ event organizer, on Facebook.
In essence, it’s a mix of both,” Haught told WTRF, a local TV news channel.

4.title: TikTok opens data to US researchers in its bid to be more transparent
4.summary:
TikTok opens data to US researchers in its bid to be more transparent The app has launched its research API after beta testing it over the past few months.
TikTok has launched its research API and has started giving more people access to its data as part of its "continued commitment to transparency and accountability," the ByteDance-owned service says.
Now, it's expanding the API's availability to researchers affiliated with non-profit academic institutions in the US.
Any proposal submitted by interested universities and researchers will have to be approved by its US Data Security (USDS) division, the new subsidiary TikTok established to comply with national security reviews in the United States.
TikTok's API could give researchers a look into the social media usage of the younger generation and an alternative source of information overall.

5.title: What being a hospice volunteer taught me about death and life
5.summary:
I wanted to be one of those hospice volunteers.
A hospice in the next county was seeking a volunteer to write the life stories of patients in its day centre.
In the outside world, death is hidden, unmentionable.
In a hospice, I’m humbled by figures in the beds, trustingly accepting the ministrations of a stranger and whispering, even when barely conscious, a thank you.
Life seems more real sometimes inside the hospice than it does back in the world of deadlines and small talk.

6.title: Neurodiverse people just need to be given a chance | Letters
6.summary:
Me too, Nick Ransom (I’ve stopped saying I ‘have autism’ – for me, being autistic is brilliant, not a burden, 6 February)!
What neurodiverse people need are opportunities to develop and people to have faith in them.
Andrew ScaifeYorkThanks to Nick Ransom for his perspective.
I turned my life around 180 degrees and now wish to support other neurodiverse people and help them feel valued by neurotypical people and organisations.
We need to be able to understand our differences before we can celebrate them, and try to avoid collateral damage.

7.title: Museums must take more care with their donors | Letter
7.summary:
Hannah Jane Parkinson’s piece underscores the importance of cultural organisations having effective due diligence processes in place to “know your donor”, a key fundraising principle set out by the Charity Commission (First Sackler, now Bet365.
The art world can’t keep taking money from companies that do us harm, 28 February).
Furthermore, an unethical sponsor with an image problem is much more likely to target its payments on the larger and better funded institutions, where their association with the arts will gain greater public profile, than community-based organisations that are struggling to make ends meet.
When many of these smaller organisations are taking on the difficult ethical questions associated with their collections, programmes and sources of funding, it is disappointing that institutions that should be offering an example of best practice – such as the British Museum and Science Museum – continue to lag behind.
Dr Chris GarrardCo-director, Culture Unstained

8.title: Microsoft explains Bing's bizarre AI chat behavior
8.summary:
Microsoft launched its Bing AI chat product for the Edge browser last week, and it's been in the news ever since — but not always for the right reasons.
However, users started noticing that Bing's bot gave incorrect information, berated users for wasting its time and even exhibited "unhinged" behavior.
To start with, the company admitted that it didn't envision Bing's AI being used for "general discovery of the world and for social entertainment."
Bing subreddit has quite a few examples of new Bing chat going out of control.
Despite those issues, testers have generally given Bing's AI good marks on citations and references for search, Microsoft said, though it needs to get better with "very timely data like live sports scores."

9.title: TikTok Will Give Away $500,000 in Live Trivia Challenges - CNET
9.summary:
If you're still looking to fill the hole in your life left by HQ Trivia, TikTok is stepping up.
From Feb. 22-26 you can compete in live trivia challenges in the app each night for a chance to win part of a $500,000 prize pool.
You can register for the trivia event starting today, Thursday, by searching #TikTokTrivia in the app or clicking the trivia widget in your "for you" feed.
Those with no wrong answers at the end of the night will split that day's prize money.
"We are in the early days of developing TikTok Trivia as we continue to introduce more ways to connect and engage on TikTok Live, and we're eager to listen to feedback from the community to continue to enhance the experience," the blog post says.

10.title: Elon Musk donated nearly $2 billion worth of Tesla stock to a charity last year, report says
10.summary:
A Tuesday SEC filing revealed Elon Musk donated $1.95 billion worth of Tesla shares to a charity last year.
Musk has gifted Tesla shares to charities in the past.
In 2021, he gave away 5 million worth of stock to an unknown charity.
The world's second richest person gave away about 11.6 million shares from August 12 to December 27 last year, per the filing.
At the end of 2022, the tech guru cashed in nearly $40 billion of Tesla stock to cover tax bills and service debts.

11.title: 'Hamilton' fundraiser set for Hispanic Federation, Flamboyan
11.summary:
“Hamilton” creator Lin-Manuel Miranda will bring his award-winning musical back to Puerto Rico for two weeks of performances in June, including a fundraiser for the Hispanic Federation and education nonprofit, the Flamboyan Foundation“Hamilton” creator Lin-Manuel Miranda will bring his award-winning musical back to Puerto Rico for two weeks of performances in June, including a fundraiser for the Hispanic Federation and education nonprofit, the Flamboyan Foundation.
Tickets for the fundraiser go on sale Monday through the Hispanic Federation.
The Hispanic Federation has invested more than $50 million in the past five years for emergency assistance and rebuilding efforts that include renewable energy and otherwise environmentally sustainable initiatives.
The Flamboyan Arts Fund has provided more than $10 million to over 100 arts organizations and 600 individual artists.
“Of course, food, water, electricity, medical care is really, really important.” organizers recall Lin-Manuel Miranda telling them.

12.title: Giving the middle finger is a ‘God-given right’, Canadian judge rules
12.summary:
Giving your neighbour the middle finger may not be polite but is protected as part of a person’s right to freedom of expression under the Canadian constitution, a judge has ruled.
In a 26-page decision, Dennis Galiatsatos dismissed a case against a man accused of harassing his neighbour in a Montreal suburb.
“To be abundantly clear, it is not a crime to give someone the finger,” he said in a ruling dated 24 February.
“Flipping the proverbial bird is a God-given, charter-enshrined right that belongs to every red-blooded Canadian,” he added, referring to Canada’s charter of rights and freedoms.
Naccache had previously accused Epstein of assaulting his parents in March 2021, a claim the judge dismissed outright.

13.title: ‘Tent boy’ ends charity camping challenge after three years
13.summary:
One teenager however, spent his nights sleeping in a tent to raise money for the hospice that looked after his friend.
“I love camping, it’s one of my favourite things and I’m definitely going to miss it,” he told the Guardian.
Honestly, it was horrible, and when there’s a heatwave your tent turns into a greenhouse.
And the North Devon hospice just took brilliant care of him and I wanted to say thank you in the biggest way I could.
The funds he raised for North Devon hospice in this time have made a real difference to the patients and families we support.”

14.title: SBF funneled $100 million in political donations for 'woke shit' and to Republicans through 2 executives to appear bipartisan, prosecutors say in new indictment
14.summary:
Sam Bankman-Fried put political donations through two FTX execs to appear bipartisan, prosecutors say.
An internal Alameda spreadsheet noted over $100 million in political contributions, according to the filing.
A CNBC analysis of his political contributions beginning in 2020 found he donated more than $13 million to causes affiliated with the Democratic party.
CC-1, prosecutors wrote, ultimately became on-paper "one of the largest Democratic donors in the 2022 midterm elections and helped further Bankman-Fried's political agenda."
Bankman-Fried preferred to "keep contributions to Republicans 'dark'," but was the real engine behind CC-2's donations to the GOP, prosecutors wrote.

15.title: Giving the middle finger is a ‘God-given right’, Canadian judge rules - The Guardian
15.summary:
Giving your neighbour the middle finger may not be polite but is protected as part of a person’s right to freedom of expression under the Canadian constitution, a judge has ruled.
In a 26-page decision, Dennis Galiatsatos dismissed a case against a man accused of harassing his neighbour in a Montreal suburb.
“To be abundantly clear, it is not a crime to give someone the finger,” he said in a ruling dated 24 February.
“Flipping the proverbial bird is a God-given, charter-enshrined right that belongs to every red-blooded Canadian,” he added, referring to Canada’s charter of rights and freedoms.
Naccache had previously accused Epstein of assaulting his parents in March 2021, a claim the judge dismissed outright.

16.title: MrBeast is pushing back against criticism for his latest charity stunt, as viewers are outraged that he keeps getting bashed for doing good deeds
16.summary:
In his latest charity video, MrBeast gave away 20,000 pairs of shoes to African students in need.
But many on Twitter struggled to wrap their heads around why MrBeast continues to be bashed for doing good deeds.
Donaldson retorted that he nor his charity Beast Philanthropy profit from their YouTube endeavors.
"100% of all revenue from beast philanthropy goes towards running my food banks and helping ease human suffering, and since inception I've personally put in millions into beast philanthropy."
In addition to defending Beast Philanthropy, Donaldson also sought to clarify the origins of his MrBeast Burger ghost kitchen business.

17.title: Refugee charity rejects Tory vice-chair’s claim they are ‘just as bad as’ people-smugglers
17.summary:
A volunteer organisation has dismissed a claim by the new Conservative deputy chair that Calais refugee charities are “just as bad as people-smugglers”.
He told the Telegraph: “You’ve got the people-smugglers, you’ve got the camps, the charities at the camps.
We do not want any individual to attempt to cross the Channel in a small boat, or by other dangerous means.
“They weren’t fleeing any war, or persecution, they told us that they wanted to come for a better life in the UK,” he claimed.
For more information see our Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties.

18.title: Want to Know Why You're Seeing Those Facebook Ads?
18.summary:
One simple update to Facebook gives users a much better overview why they see certain ads crop up again and again.
On Tuesday, Facebook parent company Meta announced it was updating Facebook to revitalize the “Why am I seeing this ad?” feature.
In any of these cases, Facebook says I can remove myself from that or any other category Facebook has decided to lump me into.
Buy for $20 from StackSocial AdvertisementYou see, Facebook knows a lot about me.
However, Meta’s new tool is a step in the right direction, even if it only comes after Meta’s ad dominance has slipped dramatically.

19.title: Fighter jets for Ukraine: The challenges of giving warplanes to Kyiv
19.summary:
"When I was at Nato and visited an airbase, planes would come back in and the engineers would have to strip out whole systems and put them back in.
It's almost like every time you drive your car you have to put a whole carburettor in," Dr Shea said.
"So they've got a very high maintenance requirement."

20.title: ‘Every day is doomsday’: how a food bank is struggling to keep up
20.summary:
Angela Gardiner, operations director at the food bank in Canterbury.
For the low-paid, there has been government help with energy bills but “no corresponding help with food”, Taylor-Gooby says.
“It can be over a tonne of stuff by the time you have put in 280 cans of this and 300 cans of that.”Volunteers from the food bank fill a van with food parcels.
They have health problems and have been accessing the food bank on and off since 2020 when James was made redundant.
“Food donations are flat, but cash donations have increased and some of our supporters have been extremely generous, so we are solvent,” he says.

21.title: You Can Get a Lifetime Subscription to Scrivener for $30 Right Now
21.summary:
Scrivener 3 is giving their lifetime subscription for 50% off until March 2—both Mac and Windows user can get the program for $30.
If you haven’t heard of Scrivener before, it’s a popular writing software that makes writing a lot more structured and easy to organize .
How to get Scrivener 3 for 50% offStacksocial is offering the $30 lifetime subscription deal on their site until March 2, just k eep in mind that you’ ll have to redeem your code within 30 days of buying .
The deal is only applicable for new users— if you’re an existing user or have previously signed up for a free trial, the deal won’t work .
That also means that you shouldn’t use the free trial to test the app before you buy it--but $30 for a lifetime subscription to Scrivener is worth it.

22.title: 'Imagining Freedom' will give $125 million to art projects focused on incarceration
22.summary:
'Imagining Freedom' will give $125 million to art projects focused on incarcerationEnlarge this image toggle caption Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking Time Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking TimeMaking and sharing art is powerful — and maybe even more so for people who are incarcerated.
She explains how Gillespie reclaimed his sense of time — and held onto his sense of self — through making his art.
Enlarge this image toggle caption Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking Time Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking TimeSince 2020, Mellon has already granted some $40 million to this effort, which it's calling Imagining Freedom.
Enlarge this image toggle caption Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking Time Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking Time"It received a lot of attention and praise as a signature piece in Marking Time," Fleetwood says.
Enlarge this image toggle caption Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking Time Xavier Hadley/Courtesy of Marking TimeMellon Foundation president Elizabeth Alexander points out that the range of grantees for Imagining Freedom is vast — ranging from larger, well-established organizations to smaller, grassroots efforts.

23.title: Choices for Youth Surpasses Coldest Night of the Year Fundraising Goal - VOCM
23.summary:
Choices for Youth held their annual fundraiser in support for young people facing homelessness this past weekend.
Hundreds of people braved the frigid temperatures in St John’s on Saturday for the Coldest Night of the Year Walk, raising over $68,000 for the cause, clearing the $50,000 goal.
Katie Keats, manager of fund development and communications with Choices For Youth, says the total is a new record.
She calls the support “touching”.
She says they saw the most walkers they have ever seen and fundraising is “through the roof.” She says it is a hard time, but people realize there are others who need support.

24.title: The Inescapable Inevitability of Fan Service Fatigue
24.summary:
And with every property, there comes a time where fans are given a bone via fan service.
But it feels like the fan service is getting out of hand.
The Flash is trying to deliver fan service of some kind, but it’s hard to say what exactly that is.
For better and worse, the film’s Illuminati portion feels like it was entirely formed with fan service in mind.
The more frequent such fan service is used, the less impactful it becomes.

25.title: Talkspace Allegedly Ignores Your Therapy Needs and Charges for Sessions You Aren't Getting
25.summary:
“Our top priority is to make high-quality mental health care as convenient and accessible as possible to our members,” said a Talkspace spokesperson .
Are you a therapist who’s had a bad experience with the mental health app industry, or a user with a story to share?
AdvertisementThe consequences for bad practices on a mental health app could be far more serious than misbehavior in another part of the tech industry.
Mental health apps can open up a new opportunity for care because they can lower the stigma associated with getting help.
But if people’s only experience with the mental health industry is sour, they may turn away from professional help forever.

26.title: Steve Bannon's ex-lawyers sue him over nearly $500,000 in unpaid legal bills
26.summary:
Steve Bannon's ex-lawyers filed a lawsuit saying he hasn't paid nearly $500,000 in legal bills.
The firm represented Bannon when he defied his January 6 subpoena.
The lawsuit, filed Friday, says the firm billed Bannon $855,487.87 but was paid only $375,000, leaving an outstanding balance of $480,487.87.
Trump pardoned Bannon shortly before leaving office, but the Manhattan district attorney's office brought a similar case against him that remains pending.
Bannon is having trouble with his lawyers in the Manhattan district attorney's case, too.

27.title: Ikea sends shelters to Turkey and Syria as big firms offer earthquake aid
27.summary:
The Ikea Foundation has sent 5,000 flatpack shelters to southern Turkey and northern Syria to house people left homeless by the earthquake last week, as companies around the world pledge help.
“The need for safe, dignified shelter against the cold and freezing temperatures is urgent and growing.”Ikea Foundation has sent 5,000 flatpack shelters to southern Turkey and northern Syria.
The modular shelters serve as temporary homes, classrooms and clinics in more than 80 countries, including Ukraine, Bangladesh and Colombia.
Dozens of other companies have said they are donating aid including food, medicine, services and money.
Mercedes-Benz is donating €1m to the Red Cross, while Porsche and Volkswagen are giving similar amounts to a Germany humanitarian aid platform.

28.title: Experience: I gave birth to the world’s ‘8 billionth baby’
28.summary:
I gave birth on 15 November last year, the day the UN projected the world population to reach 8 billion.
The Philippines Commission on Population and Development (Popcom) chose our baby as their symbolic 8 billionth baby, and brought a banner, cake and toys.
We were so happy that we were able to have baby Vinice without any complications, even if life has been difficult for us.
The nurse explained that it was to mark Vinice being the 8 billionth baby, but he thought they were asking him to pay 8bn pesos (£120m) for the cake.
Our family are also surprised at how and why she was chosen to be the 8 billionth baby.
